I think this channel just gave me the background information of how to restore the indigenous ecology of the town I grew up in. Why do I think this important? As a child, this area wasn't even a town in the legal sense. It had a great deal of natural beauty and an ecology that was self sustaining. I don't live there anymore but i do visit although its natural luster as been long lost. Other than just being affected by humans who have just come in and used and over used it, there influence has degraded the environments natural ability to heal itself and be a home for both Humans and the natural self healing environment that is a major draw to citizens and visitors. I love Humans, don't take anything that I've said to mean the opposite. I just want Humans to work in consortium with our surrounding environs. Now to let the cat out of the bag, my idea is to embrace, once again, our natural axiom of mammalian predator and pray species that have been killed off for the most part. Taking with it the naturally occurring food sources, naturally occurring flora and fauna that fed the local indigenous Americans for a millennia. It all start with the Kangaroo Rat, wish me luck!
TL;DR: mice are WILD.

I was going to propose you Pseudomonas radiodurans. But I've just discovered that there's still one organism even more resistant to radioactivity they say: Thremococcus gammatolerans. Just an idea if you want to explore. And thanks for your great videos!

Hands down, no contest, velvet ants (we call em Cow killers round here) are the most painful sting/bite/ attack I have ever experienced. And I've been stung, bitten, and attacked by many a critter lmao

Honestly, I've stepped on nails, broken my collar bone, had my foot crushed ect. And the sting from those things, in the few minutes it does hurt, is incredibly intense. Braking a bone is a dull pain over a long period of time, getting stung by a velvet ant is an unrelenting flood of absolute agony, so much so that when it does start to subside you'll litteraly get lightheaded and feel high >.<

Just a heads up: I have seen many scientific documents stating that tardigrades are NOT extremophiles. Sure, they can survive extreme environments, but that wasn’t their intention. As Hipster Hank said, they just chill in the water sucking up moss. An extremophile was specifically designed to survive such inhospitable environments.
That is their argument, I suppose.
A word that one of these papers used which I quite like is extremotolerant. Perhaps it is better suited for the water bears?

The Bdelloid Rotifer story is a baseline to the mutant-monster-creating microscopic organism in the extremely good book and movie RELIC:  An organism that can absorb and rebuild selected DNA and use it to modify the entire physical structure of an organism that it infects to match, for an increased ability to defend itself, with "a good offense is the best defense" being a big part of the DNA it selects.  A little like the monster in the recent version of the movie THE THING FROM ANOTHER WORLD, but more single-purpose specialist in its function.

As for the uneven "wins" for the kangaroo rat vs rattler - the rat can win 80000 times, but if it loses once, it's game over. The rattler can lose every strike on kangaroo rats it makes in it's entire lifetime, and as long as it's getting something else to eat, it's just another day. So it's not really much of an advantage, 23:1. Just enough to keep on keeping on.
